title: League's Lore, or the Absence There Of

embed.description: You can write all your theories about poorly explored storylines and unresolved plot points below! And yes, I know the universe is Runeterra and the continent is Valoran. My bad.

body: Today, we are going to the same place League's lore is going; nowhere.

I completely missed that "plot is overrated" story, too. Pretty hilarious in retrospect.

That statement by Abernathy was very awkward because, well, I generally expect people to do what they preach.

Abernathy wrote [only five games other than League of Legends](http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0008661/), among which Destroy All Humans! had him removed from character writing and replaced by another writer, DAH!2 was mostly forgettable and driven less by characters and more by making fun of the Cold War era, Saboteur was noted for having a decent overarching script bogged down by forgettable characters and Halo: Reach was outright retconned by Bungie due to their dislike of how Abernathy handled a major historical event in the Halo universe; it relied more on manipulative tearjerkers than the actual characters and emotional weight of the event.

So he preaches abandoning plot and focusing on games with interesting characters... despite mostly writing very forgettable characters. Like I said, *awkward*.
Honestly, I can't imagine how he got the job with that resume.

I wouldn't say something *that* harsh. He's not the best writer ever, sure, but then he wrote only five games. He's bound to slowly keep improving as he works more.

It's just that when you start complaining that game designers should abandon plot and focus on character pieces, I expect you to have written at least one character piece.

I absolutely would say something that harsh.  Riot can afford someone better, that's for sure, and he worked on DAH ten years ago.  Ten years without improvement isn't good--CERTAINLY not good enough to be given a job as the HEAD of the lore dept.

I think your correction about Jinx only proves his point. Jinx is essentially a forced meme. Riot pushed her out on all the noise about how she's oh so quirky and strange-looking and shoots people, but she has so little identity outside the noise that people struggle to even pin down her faction. Her visual design is all Piltover, so the only way you'll know she's from Zaun is if you went out of your way to look.

I personally ran into at least three separate interpretation of Jinx's character - a vindictive and homicidal psychopath a la Penguin and Harley Quinn, a madwoman with a purpose a la Joker and a punchclock villain who drops her crazy act when she's "off-duty". That people interpret her in so many ways shows how much of blank slate she is.

That's pretty much the issue with recent champions. They're all noise and marketing buzzwords with very little identity beyond that.

Actually, based on the lore there's no real way we know that Jinx is from Zaun.  The only indication that was ever given was that in her lore it says that people said that her clothing is similar to street clothes that are 'in style' in Zaun.  Apart from that, we know nothing.

Jinx's champion page on this website explicitly lists her as from Zaun, which is what I meant. The note about her street clothing resembling that of "in style" in Zaun is actually pretty silly. Are they implying everyone is wearing hotpants and bikinis in Zaun despite it being portrayed as an industrial wasteland? Is "hotpants and bikini" even a fashion style, given that it's a pretty normal thing to wear in hot weather?

Note that this also plays into how Zaun developed even less of an identity under the so-called Foundations team. Back in the day, its art direction was simply "mad science" and most of its characters didn't look human. Now that they're trying to expand into more normal-looking clothing, the coherence is simply not there. Jinx is dressed in hotpants and a bikini while Twitch is wearing a billowing Parisian longcoat you find in period pieces like Les Miserables, Phantom of the Opera and Count of Monte Cristo.

It. Makes. No. Sense.

I admit, I forgot to look at the part of champion pages that say where the champion is from, I just went off her bio.  I completely agree with you though.  Even though there was never much cohesion between the Zaunite champions, they all had at least some part of their style/design in common.  

Viktor, Singed, Twitch, and Mundo for example have a similar overall theme of 'weird science' with elements of 'dystopian steampunk' (contrasting Piltover's more positive version of steampunk).  They don't have much in common beyond that, but at least it's something.  Jinx has very little in common with any of them.  She's also not completely Piltovian, but in my opinion she's got more in common with those champions than the Zaunite ones.  From the way I've always viewed Zaun, it's a very dog-eat-dog city.  You either get ahead of competition, or you wind up on the streets (or worse).  Everything citizens do is done for a specific reason and that includes what they choose to wear.  I vaguely remember one of the JoJ articles saying that in order to be outside for very long you needed to wear a gas mask, and that the sky was constantly a greenish-grey color from the ever-present pollution and contamination.  Additionally, all of the clothing/gear of the champions mentioned previously serves a purpose, with the exception of Mundo (though that could be because all the experiments he's done on himself have warped his body so much that he has a much stronger tolerance for external contaminants).  In that kind of environment, Jinx's "hotpants and a bikini" make absolutely no sense as you said, and I can't see any Zaunite (no matter how 'crazy') risking their own life just to make a fashion statement or look cool.  

On a slightly related note, I'm not the only one that forgets about that section of Champion info-pages from time to time.  According to Kalista's 'Location/Place of Origin' thing, she's from "faction_"  It's been that way since her release.

He's spot on about one-dimensional characters. Riot sets up a champion (outfit, voice, abilities, IE a theme), makes them look interesting (VIA video or some obscure post), then leave it on some odd note that disallows it to continue as time goes on.. for whatever reason. 

Why?

Well, that's all the pro scene needs. They can cut costs on actual reasoning (lore) and instead make everything simply for appearances. Nothing more. Just in the name of the best way to make money.

Why?

Because Riot started fairly small, and with a closely-knit community, but suddenly grew gigantic. With this the higher-ups started shifting the budget towards the most profitable outcomes. All the while they give little bits of lore just so they can say they're doing something, and they're being creative, and they're open to possibilities.

What I miss about Riot is when they were more focused on the player-base, and when I say that I mean how to satisfy them, not devise the best way to drill into their wallets. They used to make LoL* interesting*, now that they've gotten a large notice for doing that they've deviated from being interesting. With the sheer amount of players they have, and time/money spent, they can do away with trying to be unique and simply cut to the chase and get our money. Had LoL grown at a more moderate rate this might not have happened, but need I remind Riot that the reason they are where they stand now is because of how interesting LoL was, **mainly due to its lore**.
